Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Engineering Chairs and Directors Conference: Preparing the Future Stewards of our Planet, July 29-31,2012, Columbus, OH

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1239114 Burken

Funds are requested to create an Environmental Engineering Chairs and Directors Conference. This conference and continuing effort will focus at establishing a continuing communications platform to address the needs of educating and training those entering the environmental engineering profession. Coordinating efforts through AEESP and AAEE, we strive to pull together the current environmental engineering department chairs and program directors from across the country for a two-day conference that will serve as the seminal event in coordinating a concerted national effort to improve and aid these programs is identifying areas of continued need and assist in the challenges of growing new programs in times of difficult university funding. This conference is organized jointly by Association of Environmental Engineering and Science Professors and the American Academy of Environmental Engineers. The proposed conference will have broad and profound impacts on the field of environmental engineering, and specifically the educational process that trains the fastest growing and most diverse field of engineering. The environmental challenges that face our nation and planet are of a grand scale, and the training of engineers to handle a field with such extensive impact on human health and prosperity is of great need. This training and education will also translate into a better understanding in the field of environmental engineering of the linkages to public health and societal well being.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop was successfully conducted at Ohio State University on July 29-31, 2012. The attendance included 54 attendees from 43 institutions and numerous professional organizations. The workshop was productive in opening discussions among the academic leaders in environmental engineering and Science in the US and also internationally. The talks were spread over two days and covered a wide range of topics from classroom methodologies to the long term vision of our field and how to meet our future challenges. The majority of the conversation was related to ABET, accreditation and broad support of curricula/pedagogy. The results were not surprising, as curricula/pedagogy and scholarly aspects of environmental engineering have other established avenues, such as ASEE and research conferences, respectively.  The topics lead to many continued conversations and the communications platform has been continues with the planning of the 2013 Chairs Workshop at AEESP conference and workshops in Golden Colorado. The initial Environmental Engineering Chairs and Directors Workshop was clearly a success in setting a path for preparing the future stewards of our planet.

 

The workshop had broad and profound impacts on the field of environmental engineering, and specifically the educational process that trains the fastest growing and most diverse field of engineering.  The environmental challenges that face our nation and planet are of a grand scale, and the training of engineers to handle a field with such extensive impact on human health and prosperity is of great need.  This training and education will also translate into a better understanding in the field of environmental engineering of the linkages to public health and societal well-being. A lasting communications platform is now developed and should be adopted by long lasting organizations, AEESP and AAEES. These collaborating organizations will help to institutionalize and support the goals set out in this workshop, far into the future.

 

The workshop participants worked to identify the need for educational resources (text books, electronic media, classroom materials, notes) and information related to novel educational approaches, such as service learning projects. These resources will be directly aimed at aiding others to incorporate the most effective methods and pedagogical approaches in educating our next generation of environmental engineers to tackle the challenges we face. AEESP Educational Committee is currently developing a platform to collect, vet, and make available unique educational materials. The intellectual merit will largely be achieved through the lasting communications platforms and avenues that are generated and enhanced due to the workshop. The impacts of this workshop will be lasting and immeasurable, much like a great teacher.

 

"A teacher affects eternity; he can never tell where his influence stops."

-  Henry Brooks Adams  1907 (1838-1918)
